content.description: On the back side of the Elevated Boulder there lies a few good short problems. Spring Loaded is the furthest right or downhill line on this side. Start laying down on some edges, and work up to a huge move (thatâ€™s more committing than difficult). Latch the jug, and top out. This is a good 3 move problem with a scary landing.
content.location: It is on the backside of Elevated Boulder and is the furthest right line on this side with an obvious jump.

content.description:
Holloway called this the hardest of his "Big Three" when he climbed it back in 1977.  Since

Trice

, another of the "Big Three", is now considered hard V12, Slapshot should be at least V13 ... if it ever gets repeated.  Since the first and only ascent, one hold has broken and another has lost some friction, making a repeat somewhat harder.  But although they are small,slippery, and sharp, there are still enough holds to climb this thing.
content.location: This route is in a scoop in the middle of the blank-looking east face.

content.description: Climb the left side of the northeast arete.

This is the low start to the Flatiron classic V8

Edging Edgio

. Start sitting at the bottom of the sweet roof matched on a rounded, sloper jug thing. Make a few incredibly difficult moves utilizing a variety of beta options (all are hard), to gain the start of

Edgio

. Finish that with relative ease. This problem, although having mediocre rock and a sharp hold or two, is really freaking cool.
content.protection:
A few pads. Watch the swing on

Edgio

....
content.location: On the main overhang of Elevated Boulder, this problem climbs the big roof.

content.description: This starts on a four-finger pocket with a nasty crystal tooth or on a sloper a few inches to its right. Pull on, then traverse right across big slopers to the right end of the big ledge. From the end of the ledge, climb out and slightly left on tiny edges to gain the top. It is steep, fun, and a little scary.
content.protection: Pad and spotter.  This problem is not that tall, but a fall toward the end could be awkward.
content.location: This route is on the southern end of the east face.  Find the biggest holds on the east face, then move about 12 feet left to find the start.
